author: By David E. Sanger
title: U.S. Says Russia Sent Saboteurs Into Ukraine to Create Pretext for Invasion
description: The Biden administration said the operatives were trained in urban warfare and explosives and could try to stage an incident.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House accused Moscow on Friday of sending saboteurs into eastern Ukraine to stage an incident that could provide President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with a pretext for ordering an invasion of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: The Obamacare sign-up deadline is Saturday, and stimulus subsidies are driving record enrollments.
description: The subsidies, established by Congress last year, make insurance less expensive for nearly everyone who buys it this year.
content: For Americans who need health insurance, now is the time to sign up. The end of the 2022 open enrollment period for Obamacare marketplaces in most states is Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Warner
title: A Scheherazade for Our Times
description: For Nahid Kazemi’s version of the fabled storyteller, empathy rules.
content: SHAHRZAD & THE ANGRY KINGBy Nahid Kazemi
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Mike Isaac
title: Jan. 6 Committee Subpoenas Four Big Tech Firms
description: The panel investigating the attack on the Capitol is demanding information from Alphabet, Meta, Reddit and Twitter.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol issued subpoenas on Thursday to four major social media companies — Alphabet, Meta, Reddit and Twitter — criticizing them for allowing extremism to spread on their platforms and saying they have failed to cooperate adequately with the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Companies’ Vaccine Mandates Get Messier
description: The Supreme Court blocked the Biden administration’s rule, making corporate policies more fraught.
content: The Supreme Court yesterday blocked the Biden administration from enforcing a vaccine-or-testing mandate for large employers, parts of which were set to go into effect on Monday. In the ruling, the court said that the Labor Department does not have the federal authority to issue the mandate. The justices allowed a narrower mandate for health care workers at facilities receiving federal funds to go ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The C.D.C. conceded that cloth masks do not protect against the virus as effectively as other masks.
description: The update in guidance comes as Covid cases continue to soar.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday clarified its stance on various kinds of masks, acknowledging that the cloth masks frequently worn by Americans do not offer as much protection as surgical masks or respirators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Biden Will Nominate Three New Fed Officials
description: The nominees would bring more diverse leadership to the Fed, which has struggled to expand its ranks.
content: President Biden plans to nominate three new Federal Reserve officials as he seeks to remake the central bank at a critical economic moment, a White House official familiar with the matter said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Scream’ at 25: How Meta Can You Get?
description: After 25 years, the influence of Wes Craven’s self-aware slasher still looms large, both for the imitators that followed and the backlash it set off.
content: A striking blond college student sprawls nude across a dormitory bed, a white silk sheet barely covering her body. From the shadows emerges her paramour, who reaches out to caress the woman’s shoulder — when she suddenly realizes that it isn’t her paramour at all. The man wrings her tender neck. She screams. He raises a huge, gleaming knife and plunges it into her flesh three, four, five times, as great gouts of cherry-red blood splatter the wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Boom! Go the (Tech) Subpoenas
description: A reckoning for Big Tech over its role in the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.
content: After seeking information from the likes of Steve Bannon, Mark Meadows, Sean Hannity and the House minority leader, Kevin McCarthy, Congress’s select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol was inevitably going to get around to the tech companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pink masks? No thanks, say some Italian police officers.
description: A spokesman for one union said the objection was not from “a prejudice against the color,” but reflected concerns about decorum.
content: ROME — When Inspector Luca Sita picked up two new N95 masks at his police station in Ferrara in central Italy on Thursday, he was thrown for a loop: One mask was white, and the other was pink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Names Official to Counter Foreign Election Interference
description: The director of national intelligence appointed a C.I.A. veteran to the post amid delays in congressional approval of money for a new office to oversee threats to American politics from abroad.
content: WASHINGTON — The director of national intelligence, Avril D. Haines, has appointed a new officer to oversee threats to elections, filling a critical role in the nation’s efforts to counter foreign election interference, her office said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson’s Office Apologizes to Queen for Parties
description: The prime minister’s office said it was “deeply regrettable” that two parties took place at Downing Street the night before Prince Philip’s funeral. Mr. Johnson was not accused of attending either of them.
content: LONDON — Capping a week of abject contrition, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain apologized on Friday to Buckingham Palace for raucous parties held in Downing Street the night before Queen Elizabeth II buried her husband, Prince Philip, in a socially distanced ceremony that left her grieving alone in a choir stall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Critics Say I.M.F. Loan Fees Are Hurting Nations in Desperate Need
description: Democratic lawmakers say the global fund’s surcharges for emergency relief siphon away money that countries need to fight the pandemic.
content: At a time when the coronavirus pandemic is fueling a rapid rise in inequality and debt, a growing number of policymakers and economists are pressuring the International Monetary Fund to eliminate extra fees it charges on loans to struggling nations because they siphon away scarce funds that could instead be used to battle Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The White House nominates a diverse slate of candidates to the Fed Board.
description: The Biden administration is picking Sarah Bloom Raskin, who has a long record of pushing tougher regulation, as the nation’s top bank cop.
content: President Biden nominated three new Federal Reserve officials on Friday as he seeks to remake the central bank at a critical economic moment, announcing a slate of candidates that would make for the most diverse Fed Board of Governors in the institution’s 108-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Shortz
title: And the Winners Are, Part 2: The ‘Red Herring Murder’ Mystery Contest
description: The winners of the second contest in the 2021 “Puzzle Mania” section.
content: Well, that was different — and by all accounts a lot of fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Fires 2 Ballistic Missiles After Lashing Out Over Sanctions
description: The launches came after the country threatened “stronger and certain reaction” if the United States helped imposed more sanctions over the North’s recent missile tests.
content: SEOUL — North Korea fired two ballistic missiles on Friday, its third missile test this month, hours after it warned of “stronger and certain reaction” if the United States helped impose more sanctions on the North in response to its recent series of missile tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York’s Ban on Evictions Is Expiring. What Happens Now?
description: The moratorium’s end presents Gov. Kathy Hochul with a potential challenge as she prepares to run for a full term.
content: For most of the pandemic, New York State has maintained a strict eviction moratorium, a safeguard that many elected officials and housing advocates say has prevented a cascading crisis in a state with an enormous number of struggling renters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Sidney Poitier and the Black Voice
description: He was a pioneer — in the transitional sense.
content: Sidney Poitier’s passing has me thinking about the Black voice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Christine Chung
title: Baltimore Prosecutor Charged With Perjury and Filing False Loan Applications
description: Marilyn Mosby, the state’s attorney for Baltimore City, is accused of lying about pandemic hardships to withdraw retirement funds and of making false statements in her mortgage applications to buy two Florida vacation homes.
content: Marilyn Mosby, Baltimore’s top prosecutor, was indicted Thursday on charges that she perjured herself to obtain money from a retirement fund and made false statements on loan applications to buy two vacation homes in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Oscar Lopez
title: Mass Trials in Cuba Deepen Its Harshest Crackdown in Decades
description: Following nationwide demonstrations last year, more than 60 people were put on trial this week, some facing up to 30 years behind bars.
content: Detained protesters in Cuba could get up to 30 years in prison as they face the largest and most punitive mass trials on the island since the early years of the revolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How the Head of a Jazz Nonprofit Spends Her Sundays
description: Alina Bloomgarden believes that music education can reduce recidivism. Many renowned jazz artists have joined her cause.
content: Alina Bloomgarden started Music on the Inside, a nonprofit that connects jazz artists with incarcerated people (or those recently released from prisons and jails) for lessons, concerts and mentoring. Her inspiration for founding the program seven years ago was Louis Armstrong, who was arrested as a boy and sent to reform school, where he learned to play the horn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dawn Perry
title: The Secret to Easy Homemade Pizza
description: You don’t have to struggle with from-scratch dough when store-bought French bread can step in.
content: Making pizza at home sounds fun, but homemade pizza dough can be finicky, even if you’ve had a lot of practice. Still, that doesn’t mean delivery is the only way to satisfy a craving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Amtrak temporarily reduces train service amid Omicron surge within its ranks.
description: About 8 percent of departures to be suspended for the next 10 weeks.
content: Amtrak said on Friday that it will temporarily reduce service on some trains because of staffing challenges stemming from a surge in cases of the Omicron variant among workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Alec Baldwin Will Turn in Phone to Investigators This Week, Lawyer Says
description: The sheriff’s office in Santa Fe said nearly a month had elapsed since a search warrant was issued for the phone, but it had not yet been surrendered.
content: A lawyer for Alec Baldwin said on Thursday that the actor would turn over his cellphone “this week” to authorities investigating his fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set for the film “Rust,” nearly a month after detectives secured a search warrant for the device.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Maskless and Inaccurate
description: The Supreme Court offers a window into partisan Covid fallacies.
content: When the Supreme Court justices emerged from the red drapes at the front of the courtroom last Friday and took their seats — to hear arguments about President Biden’s vaccine mandate — all but one of the justices there were wearing masks. The exception was Neil Gorsuch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: States appeal a judge’s decision to throw out their Facebook antitrust case.
description: The states’ central claim is that Facebook acquired competitors — particularly Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014 — in a predatory manner, by crushing competition.
content: WASHINGTON — Nearly four dozen states on Friday asked a federal appeals court to reconsider an antitrust lawsuit against Facebook that a judge threw out last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Retail sales fell in December, a slowdown in a robust holiday shopping season.
description: Despite that 1.9 percent decline, sales for the fourth quarter of 2021 jumped 17.1 percent as consumers began their holiday shopping earlier.
content: Retail sales fell 1.9 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported on Friday, reflecting a slowdown during an otherwise robust holiday shopping season that started earlier in the year for many consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: How to Find a Quality Mask (and Avoid Counterfeits)
description: Knowing which mask to pick and making sure it’s not a fake requires the sleuthing skills of a forensic investigator. Our guide can help.
content: The fast-spread of the infectious Omicron variant has prompted many people to try to upgrade to a higher-quality medical mask. But that’s easier said than done.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ricki Lake Says Her Late Husband Helped Her Find Love Anew
description: The former talk show host Ricki Lake and Ross Burningham wed in an intimate backyard celebration in Malibu, Calif.
content: Ricki Lake said she doesn’t care if she sounds “hippy-dippy woo-woo.” The actor, documentary filmmaker and former talk show host credits her second husband, Christian Evans, with leading her to her third.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What Californians Love About Winter
description: It’s more than just the absence of months of snow and subzero temperatures.
content: A reader who moved from New York to the Bay Area emailed me recently, “The best part of winter in California is that there is no winter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura May Todd
title: At Laboratorio Paravicini, Vintage-Feeling Italian Ceramics Are New Again
description: From its start in the mid-1990s, the beloved Milanese line has adhered to romantically old-fashioned methods and designs.
content: Turning off the bustling shopping thoroughfare that is Milan’s Via Torino, where clanging trams zoom past chain stores such as Zara and Sephora, and onto Via Nerino, with its stately gray stone buildings that keep the narrow lane in shadow, is akin to stepping into an alternate world. Still, the first street marks the southern border of the city’s historic Cinque Vie neighborhood, which is built atop the even older remains of an ancient Roman settlement, and is home to a thriving network of galleries and artisan workshops. Among them, behind an inconspicuous carved wood door on Via Nerino, is the atelier of Laboratorio Paravicini, the hand-painted ceramics line that Costanza Paravicini founded in 1995, and now runs with two of her children, Benedetta and Margherita Medici Di Marignano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Edward Kirkland, Who Helped Preserve Historic Chelsea, Dies at 96
description: He played a less public but powerful role in creating the High Line, Hudson River Park and landmark districts in the Manhattan neighborhood.
content: Edward S. Kirkland, a preservationist who played a role in shaping some of the most beloved and characteristic sections of Lower Manhattan, including the High Line, Hudson River Park and Chelsea’s historic districts, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Google pays $1 billion for a London office building.
description: The internet giant, planning on employees returning to the office for a few days a week, is building another $1 billion office less than two miles away.
content: Google said Friday that it would spend $1 billion to purchase a London office building, making it the owner of another high-priced piece of real estate as the internet giant bets on an eventual return to office for its employees around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Lentils You’re Loving
description: Lidey Heuck’s recipe, with sweet potatoes and spinach, is inspired by dal, but run through with Thai elements.
content: One thing I miss from the pre-Covid era is eating at friends’ homes, which I do sparingly at this point, and only with the precautions that you’d imagine. I love seeing what my friends decide to make, a fascination that is surely related to the fact that I’m a professional recipe recommender. Trying their dishes, another joy, is an altogether different thing from eating off the menu at a restaurant — though I miss that, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Antonia Hitchens
title: Hope Gained and Lost, in New Fiction From Around the World
description: In novels from Ireland, Sweden and Japan: tales of terminal illness, a gruesome murder and time travel.
content: AS YOU WERE By Elaine Feeney 392 pp. Biblioasis. Paper, $16.95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How Much Deference Do Elite U.S. Colleges Deserve?
description: It has gotten harder to justify giving them special treatment.
content: I have a feeling that elite colleges and universities are going to have a hard time dealing with allegations that they have illegally colluded by coordinating their financial aid policies. It’s not just a question of whether they broke the law, although the allegations in the class-action lawsuit filed on Sunday appear damning. It’s a broader question of whether Ivy League universities and other renowned institutions still deserve deference and freedom of action because of their contributions to society — or whether they should be scrutinized like any other self-interested institutions, such as tire manufacturers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: A Burnout Crisis
description: Around one in five health care workers have quit since the pandemic began.
content: The U.S. is experiencing a crisis of burned-out health care workers. For nearly two years, overwhelmed nurses, doctors and hospital staff have raced to save the lives of hundreds of thousands of people from a fast-moving and often mystifying virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Belsky
title: Is the Arizona Cardinals’ Title Drought the Result of a Curse?
description: The Arizona Cardinals, owners of the longest championship drought in major American sports, enter the N.F.L. playoffs with, some say, a curse the team won’t acknowledge.
content: Jay Zimner is by most measures a rational man. Zimner, a 44-year-old lawyer, leads a thriving real estate and litigation practice in New York City even as he comanages a Manhattan chapter of BNI, the networking organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Some Bronx High-Rise Tenants Say Return After Fire Is Too Fast
description: Residents of the Bronx high-rise where 17 people died in a smoky blaze gathered to express frustration over their current circumstances.
content: Mabintou Tunkara was lugging grocery bags stuffed with clothes and other belongings when she walked out of the Twin Parks North West apartment building on Thursday.

title: Boris Johnson apologizes to the queen for 2 pandemic parties at Downing Street.

author: By James Barron
title: New York’s Eviction Moratorium Is Ending
description: A financial lifeline for tenants, it was imposed early in the pandemic and extended time and again. It will expire on Saturday.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at New York’s eviction moratorium, which is about to expire. We’ll also look at the first comprehensive Sherlock Holmes exhibition in New York in more than 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sebastian Modak
title: For Travel or Hibernation: New Audiobooks to Uplift, Soothe or Terrify
description: What to listen to this winter, from a dark, dystopian fantasy to a guide to enjoying the here and now.
content: I have become so accustomed to combining daily walks with audiobooks that I associate certain sections of my neighborhood with specific narrative moments from the dozens of works I listened to over the course of 2021. This curve in the path is when I found out who the murderer is; that oak tree is the one I stared at after I hit pause and contemplated some tiny morsel of life wisdom. But in between those meandering sessions, I’ve occasionally experimented with different listening habits. Can I close my eyes and listen for 30 minutes of a story without drifting into a nap? Can I find audiobooks that offer not just passive entertainment or fleeting lessons, but concrete self-improvement? Can I explore the fringes of the audiobook landscape until I find something that makes me rethink what an audiobook even is?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Insurers say Saturday is too soon to meet the White House’s goals on rapid tests.
description: Starting Saturday, new federal rules will require private insurers to cover the at-home coronavirus tests that Americans buy in pharmacies and other stores. The new system could, in theory, allow millions of people to pick up tests at thousands of locations without spending any money.
content: Starting Saturday, new federal rules will require private insurers to cover the at-home coronavirus tests that Americans buy in pharmacies and other stores. The new system could, in theory, allow millions of people to pick up tests at thousands of locations without spending any money.

author: By Vanessa Veselka and Clayton Cotterell
title: I’m a Longtime Union Organizer. But I Had Never Seen Anything Like This.
description: After a spate of deaths, a group of health care workers in Oregon decided that to save lives, they needed a union.
content: Last winter, workers at a memory care facility in western Oregon decided they were done watching the residents suffer. Conditions at the Rawlin at Riverbend, a 72-bed home in Springfield, were horrific because of critically low staffing and a lack of training. Elderly residents screamed from their rooms for assistance, and workers had to make the kinds of decisions that people are forced to make in war: Do you take precious time to do emergency wound care, even though you aren’t quite sure how, knowing that it means other residents might sit in their own feces for hours or trip and fall in the hallways? Do you stop to feed a resident who has trouble swallowing, knowing that others may not be fed if you do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Dancing That Unfolds Like a Prayer
description: The Northern Irish choreographer Oona Doherty looks at despair through an ethereal lens at the Irish Arts Center.
content: The choreographer Oona Doherty grasps that in everybody — and in every body — there is a point of tension between hard and soft, tough and vulnerable, pleasure and pain. For all their posturing, her characters, anonymous working-class youth from Belfast, ache. And while her movement language creates an exacting physical entity, transcendence comes through an inner battle: fighting the hard to find the soft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Katharine Tramontana
title: ‘There’s Not Just One Type of Porn’: Erika Lust’s Alternative Vision
description: The Swedish moviemaker thinks pornography can create a society that sees sexuality as myriad and joyful, and where women’s pleasure matters.
content: BARCELONA, Spain — When Billie Eilish called pornography “a disgrace” in a recent radio interview, the quote made headlines. The Grammy-winning musician said she had started watching at around age 11, to learn how to have sex, and that she was now angry about the way she felt porn misrepresented women.

content: As the Omicron variant of the coronavirus continues to surge onboard cruise ships, forcing several cruise lines to cancel and postpone voyages, Atlantis Events, a gay and lesbian tour operator, is preparing to launch one of its biggest events on Sunday: a 5,500-person Caribbean cruise marking the company’s 30th anniversary.

title: ‘I Was Not Whole’: Why a Grandfather Went Back to College
description: Ciro Scala had to delay school. Fifty years later, he returned, earning two degrees and the respect of younger students.
content: In the fall of 1959, Ciro Scala, just out of high school, was commuting to a clerical job in Times Square from Staten Island and also going to City College, uptown on Convent Avenue in the evenings. The trip home — which relied on the IRT to Lower Manhattan, the Staten Island Ferry and then a bus to New Brighton — took about two and a half hours, although sometimes it extended to three, getting him home, in every instance, past midnight. Ground down, he eventually gave up and stopped attending classes, which he did with a sorrowful resignation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: ‘Superload’ Lumbers Across Pennsylvania, Two Lanes Wide and as Big as Two Whales
description: A mammoth tractor-trailer is hauling a tank from a decommissioned nuclear training site for disassembly near Pittsburgh. Top speed: 30 m.p.h.
content: It is called a superload, and for good reason: The highway behemoth is longer than five fire trucks and weighs as much as two blue whales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon bring us back to a transformative period in American history.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is from an important recent book by a Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times alumna, Isabel Wilkerson. “The Warmth of Other Suns” was published in 2011 and chronicles the Great Migration, the movement of about six million Black people from the American South to the rest of the United States throughout the 20th century. The book examines the paths taken by three real members of this diaspora; one, Ida Mae Brandon Gladney, traveled from Mississippi to Chicago, which is the setting for this puzzle’s excerpt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan B. Garland
title: When a Diagnosis Demands a Long-Term Money Strategy
description: Financial planning for people with chronic diseases is complicated and multifaceted. Start by building a team of people to help.
content: When Fred Schwartz was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in 1994, the financial challenges that lay ahead were not top of mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Dutch Royals to Retire Golden Coach With Echoes of Colonialism
description: The horse-drawn coach, a gift from the city of Amsterdam to Queen Wilhelmina in 1898, has long been the target of critics.
content: The Dutch royal family will stop using a horse-drawn gold-covered coach dating from the late 19th-century that has long drawn criticism for its painted panel glorifying the Netherlands’ history of colonialism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Rafkin
title: In Lockdown, a Long-Distance Romance Grew Stronger
description: Maheisha Adams and Meerim Ilyas met at a conference in Ukraine in 2019, and solidified their bond a year later while quarantining together in Washington.
content: Meerim Ilyas and Maheisha Adams met in April of 2019 while attending the European Lesbian Conference in Kyiv, Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: Their First Date ‘Felt Like Christmas’
description: Yasmin Quiles and NaVell Shorter met about 10 years ago at a Scotch-tasting event, and soon became intoxicated by each other’s energy.
content: NaVell Shorter knew he was thinking too much about how to impress Yasmin Quiles on their first date. So he took a pause and regrouped. “I was like, don’t put too much pressure on yourself,” he said. “Everybody knows Yasmin knows what’s good. But I’m going to show her what’s better.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Anti-Trump Republicans Diverge on 2022 Midterms
description: Disaffected conservatives broke with their party to oust a sitting president. Some still hope to have a say in the G.O.P.’s future.
content: For those Republicans who dare to publicly oppose Donald J. Trump, politics can be a lonely place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: How the Wreck of a Cruise Liner Changed an Italian Island
description: Ten years ago the Costa Concordia ran aground off the Tuscan island of Giglio, killing 32 people and entwining the lives of others forever.
content: GIGLIO PORTO, Italy — The curvy granite rocks of the Tuscan island of Giglio lay bare in the winter sun, no longer hidden by the ominous, stricken cruise liner that ran aground in the turquoise waters of this marine sanctuary ten years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Where Can I Find a Stylish Winter Boot?
description: A reader asks for guidance in finding footwear that delivers both in looks and warmth.
content: My usual suggestion of first resort when it comes to cold weather dressing ideas is simple: Look thee to the Sundance Film Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘2021’s Most Fascinating Animals’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about some of the unusual creatures The Times reported on in 2021. Then, they will research another unique animal.
content: This lesson is a part of our new Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Giulia Heyward
title: No Shots, No Day Care: Parents of Kids Under 5 Stuck in Grueling Limbo
description: Facing an uncontrolled surge of virus cases, parents of young children are again forced to wrestle with child care crises as the rest of the world appears eager to move on.
content: HOUSTON — Twice last year, Margaret Schulte and her husband, Jason Abercrombie, traveled 11 hours round-trip to Louisiana from their home in Tulsa, Okla., in the hopes of vaccinating their children, who were 2 and 4, against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Fear of Russia Brings New Purpose and Unity to NATO, Once Again
description: After years of drift, Trumpian ridicule and failure in Afghanistan, Russian demands for a new Iron Curtain in Europe have created unity in the alliance, at least for now.
content: BRUSSELS — After the collapse of the Soviet Union, NATO was an alliance in search of a role. Some suggested that if NATO did not “go out of area,” beyond Europe, it would “go out of business.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: More Young Kids Are Getting Sick From Cannabis Edibles
description: As states legalize cannabis, a growing number of children are inadvertently consuming marijuana-infused foods.
content: Mouthwatering chocolate, soft and chewy cookies, lollipops and fruity gummies: Marijuana edibles often look just like regular foods. Some candies even mimic familiar brands like Skittles or Starburst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Shortz
title: And the Winners Are, Part 1: Super Mega
description: The results of the 2021 Puzzle Mania Super Mega crossword contest.
content: The “Super Mega” crossword by Jeff Chen in December’s Puzzle Mania section was, apparently, pretty challenging, because a lower percentage of solvers than usual got it right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: How Djokovic Spurred Debate on the Fairness of Border Policies
description: The past week has thrown Australia’s strict border control and detention system into the spotlight.
content: A steady trickle of passers-by stopped in front of the Park Hotel in Melbourne on Saturday, pausing to take photos, read the chalk writing scrawled on the building — “free them all” and “30 children locked inside here and tortured for 3,092 days” — or peer up, trying to catch a glimpse of Novak Djokovic, the tennis star who had been detained inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Waiting for Omicron
description: I’m ready to get it over with, but it’s not that simple.
content: You’re not supposed to want to get Omicron just to get it over with. In article after article, experts warn against trying to catch the virus in the hope of putting it behind you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Looking for a Wedding Date, He Found a Partner Instead
description: Nicholas Cerbone matched with Emily Sundel on the dating app Bumble while he was looking for someone to attend his brother’s wedding with him.
content: Nicholas Cerbone was looking for someone to bring to his brother’s wedding when he matched with Emily Sundel on the dating app Bumble on May 30, 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

title: President Biden will nominate 3 new Fed officials, diversifying leadership.
description: President Biden plans to nominate three new Federal Reserve officials as he seeks to remake the central bank at a critical economic moment, a White House official familiar with the matter said on Thursday.
content: President Biden plans to nominate three new Federal Reserve officials as he seeks to remake the central bank at a critical economic moment, a White House official familiar with the matter said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Bridget Everett Shows Off Her Softer Side. And a Bra.
description: “Somebody Somewhere,” a bittersweet comedy on HBO, will likely surprise viewers who know Everett as a self-proclaimed “cabaret wildebeest.”
content: Sometimes Bridget Everett, the actress, comedian and self-proclaimed “cabaret wildebeest,” wonders what would have happened if she had never left Kansas. She has a pretty good idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Sydney Harper, Daniel Guillemette, Rikki Novetsky, Mooj Zadie, Robert Jimison, Alexandra Leigh Young, Eric Krupke, Larissa Anderson, John Ketchum and Brad Fisher
title: The Life and Legacy of Sidney Poitier
description: How the first Black man to win an Oscar transformed not only American cinema, but also America itself.
content: Sidney Poitier, who was Hollywood’s first Black matinee idol and who helped open the door for Black actors in the film industry, died last week. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Is This Stadium in England or Wales? The Team Needs to Know.
description: The English soccer club Chester F.C. postponed a game after Welsh health officials claimed authority over its home. In an era when once loose British borders are stratifying, a curiosity may become a crisis.
content: Chas Sumner has heard the quiz question in all its forms. There was the one that asked: “Which club has an international border running along the halfway line of its stadium?” Or this one: “Which soccer team gets changed in one country but plays in another?” Or: “Where can you take a corner in England, but score a goal in Wales?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Lonely? Get in Line. A Covid Test Line.
description: Tales of New Yorkers singing together, getting impromptu architecture lessons and making new friends.
content: Deni Bonet was considering leaving New York. “Being in the arts, it’s been really tough,” said Ms. Bonet, an electric violinist and singer-songwriter, who had watched many friends and colleagues move out of the city over the past two years. “I needed a New York moment to remember why I live here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Howard Solomon, 94, Dies; His Business Success Had a Personal Connection
description: After one of his sons fell into a deep depression, he helped him recover. He later licensed an antidepressant that was a boon to his pharmaceutical company.
content: Howard Solomon was building the pharmaceutical company Forest Laboratories, not by manufacturing drugs but by licensing them. In his search for deals in the United States and Europe, he learned about citalopram, a Danish antidepressant. He did not license it, though, believing the U.S. market was saturated with drugs to treat depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Neil Vigdor
title: Winter Storm Threatens Disruption Across Wide Stretch of the U.S.
description: “There’s more uncertainty than usual,” one forecaster said.
content: A powerful winter storm crept across the upper Midwest on Friday, tracking on a circuitous path that forecasters said could create a cascade of power outages, hazardous travel conditions and deepening supply-chain problems across a vast section of the country extending from the South to the East Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Clock Is Ticking, but M.L.B. and its Players Remain Apart
description: A rare negotiating session did not appear to please either side. Time is running out to avoid delaying spring training.
content: Major League Baseball’s spring training is scheduled to start in a month and the 2022 regular season is supposed to kick off on March 31. Neither can happen until the owners of M.L.B.’s 30 teams and the players strike a new labor agreement, and with little progress so far, the clock is ticking on whether baseball can begin on time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Have You Ever Benefited From Rejection?
description: Axel Webber didn’t get into Juilliard — but he did become an internet star. In your life, has rejection ever been a blessing in disguise?
content: Think about a time when you experienced rejection. How did it feel in the moment? How do you feel about it now?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Citigroup’s vaccine requirement prompts a flurry of employees to get shots.
description: Unvaccinated employees will lose their jobs by the end of the month.
content: Citigroup’s unvaccinated staff members in the United States have rushed to get shots — or request exemptions — just before its coronavirus vaccination requirement kicks in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: The Kunga Was a Status Symbol Long Before the Thoroughbred
description: A new study finds the first known instance of a human-engineered hybrid, bred from a donkey and a Syrian wild ass 4,500 years ago.
content: In ancient Mesopotamia 4,500 years ago, long before horses arrived in the region, another spirited member of the equine family, the kunga, took a starring role in pulling four-wheeled wagons into battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Eddie Basinski, Who Played Both the Infield and the Fiddle, Dies at 99
description: Basinski, who spent time with the Dodgers and the Pirates, was a rare double threat: a major league ballplayer and a trained violinist.
content: Eddie Basinski, an infielder with the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Pittsburgh Pirates of the 1940s who, in an unusual combination of abilities, was also a concert violinist, died on Saturday in Gladstone, Ore., near Portland. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian J. O'Connor
title: Stock Sectors That Go Up Usually Then Fall. Guess What Happened in 2021?
description: The returns for 2020 and 2021 followed a familiar pattern. One year’s winning investment picks were losers the next year.
content: Chasing one year’s hot market sectors often means losing money in the next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley
title: Alec Baldwin Turns Over His Phone in ‘Rust’ Investigation
description: Detectives investigating the actor’s fatal shooting of a cinematographer on a film set in New Mexico had gotten a search warrant for the phone nearly a month ago.
content: The actor Alec Baldwin turned his phone in to the police in Suffolk County, N.Y., on Friday morning, his lawyer said, starting a process that will allow investigators to collect data related to his fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust” last year in New Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: They Remodeled Before Covid. Here’s What They Regret Now.
description: The live-work space in Jersey City, N.J., should have been ideal for lockdown. But hindsight born of a pandemic taught them a few things.
content: When Beverly O’Mara and Mark Uriu converted their loft in Jersey City, N.J., into a live-work space in 2015, they envisioned an airy, open apartment where Ms. O’Mara could have an art studio and Mr. Uriu could work from home on occasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Why Is Everyone So Angry? We Investigated.
description: The Times writer at large Sarah Lyall captured a national feeling with her recent article on consumer rage. She shares how the story came together.
content: The stories of bad customer behavior began trickling out in the summer of 2020, when businesses that had closed in the early part of the coronavirus pandemic began to reopen to a new, angry mood  in the United States. At a restaurant struggling with staff and food shortages in Massachusetts, for instance, a group of diners grew so furious at the long wait for food that they demanded it be boxed up — and then theatrically dumped the whole order, uneaten, into the garbage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: To Fight Covid, We Need to Think Less Like Doctors
description: Leaders are too focused on risks to individuals versus the population as a whole.
content: Caring for an individual and protecting a population require different priorities, practices and ways of thinking. While it may sound counterintuitive, to heal the country and put our Covid-19 response on the right track, we need to think less like doctors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Campbell Robertson and Sabrina Imbler
title: New Virus Cases Begin to Slow in U.S. Cities Where Omicron Hit First
description: Reports of infections are falling in Cleveland, Newark and Washington, suggesting that a national peak may be approaching.
content: At another bleak moment of the pandemic in the United States — with nearly 800,000 new cases a day, deaths rising and federal medical teams deploying to overwhelmed hospitals — glints of progress have finally started to emerge. In a handful of places that were among the first to see a surge of the Omicron variant last month, reports of new coronavirus infections have started to level off or decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Benveniste
title: In the Smartphone Era, Millennials Are Buying Film Cameras
description: In this Tuesday’s puzzle, “SLR” was the answer to the clue “Certain camera, for short.”
content: This is Clued In, a column that will give you insight into some of the New York Times Crossword clues and answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: For Two Fraternity Brothers, an Even Stronger Bond
description: Scott Malamut and Dr. Thomas McConville started dating a year after they met as members of the same fraternity at Cornell University in 2006.
content: Scott Hunter Malamut and Dr. Thomas Howe McConville met in January 2006 as members of the same fraternity at Cornell University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: One Indelible Scene: When a Woman Takes the Wheel in ‘Licorice Pizza’
description: After letting Alana Haim and her character drift and idle, Paul Thomas Anderson gives you a reason to cheer: “Hardcore, hardcore Alana!”
content: In the final stretch of Paul Thomas Anderson’s “Licorice Pizza,” the rocker-turned-film-goddess Alana Haim climbs into the driver’s seat of a truck and takes off with the movie. Her character — a rootless adult also named Alana — has been meandering through the story, which takes place in 1973. For reasons known only to Anderson, Alana has been hanging out with Gary (Cooper Hoffman), an operator, recently turned 16, whose latest hustle is selling water beds. They need to deliver a bed to a customer, but since Gary isn’t yet driving, Alana is the one behind the wheel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Survivor993 Is Not Alone: Lawsuits Show Abuse at School for At-Risk Teens
description: The Family Foundation School, closed in 2014, has long faced accusations of using improper methods. Decades later, lawsuits submitted under the Child Victims’ Act have exposed rampant claims of physical, emotional and sexual abuse.
content: The approach to the little reform school in the woods seemed to be from a storybook, a winding road bringing new students to its remote campus, with dormitories and a red barn perched beside a pond. Teenagers who weren’t in class sat quietly on porches or carried buckets across a broad lawn, part of the regimen of chores in a program that promised to rehabilitate — to cure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Nicholas Fandos
title: John Katko, Republican Who Voted to Impeach Trump, Won’t Seek Re-election
description: Increasingly marginalized from conservatives at home and in Washington, Mr. Katko also faced a brutal general election campaign in his left-leaning New York district.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative John Katko of New York, a centrist Republican who broke with his party last year to vote to impeach former President Donald J. Trump, announced on Friday that he would not run for re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil Producers Aren’t Keeping Up With Demand, Causing Prices to Stay High
description: OPEC Plus, the United States and others have been slow to ramp up output, lagging production goals.
content: Nearly two years ago the world’s oil producers slammed on the brakes and drastically cut production as the pandemic gripped the world’s economies. The sharp pullback came with an implicit promise that as factories reopened and planes returned to the air, the oil industry would revive, too, gradually scaling up production to help economies return to prepandemic health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Radtke
title: The Girl Detective Goes Digital
description: The graphic novelist Kristen Radtke imagines Nancy Drew stories if they existed in the age of the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Counter the Winter Chill With This Farro and Gruyère Gratin
description: Melissa Clark takes earthy grains and bakes them with caramelized mushrooms and loads of cheese for a satisfying meatless meal.
content: Quick-cooking farro, with its nutty flavor and plump, chewy texture, is the darling of the grain bowl, the star of countless salads and the foundation of many traditional Italian soups.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Robert Gottlieb on ‘Garbo’ and ‘Babbitt’
description: Gottlieb talks about his own new biography and the work of Sinclair Lewis, and Carl Bernstein discusses “Chasing History.”
content: The writer and editor Robert Gottlieb does double duty on this week’s podcast. He talks about the life and career of Sinclair Lewis, on the occasion of the 100th anniversary of “Babbitt,” Lewis’s best-selling novel about the narrow-mindedness and conformity of middle-class America in the first half of the 20th century. But first, he talks about his own new book, “Garbo,” a biography of the movie star Greta Garbo, whose impact on the culture was matched by the sense of mystery that surrounded her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Man Arrested in Shooting of 19-Year-Old Worker at East Harlem Burger King
description: The employee, Kristal Bayron-Nieves, was killed on Sunday when the store was robbed. The police said on Friday that a 30-year-old man was charged with the murder.
content: A man who the police say fatally shot a 19-year-old worker at a Burger King in Upper Manhattan during a botched robbery has been arrested and charged with murder, Mayor Eric Adams and other officials said at news conference on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Jail Unions Gain a Powerful Supporter: The New Mayor
description: Eric Adams has reversed some measures enacted to regain control over the crisis at Rikers Island, in an early victory for the correction officers’ unions.
content: Vincent N. Schiraldi, the commissioner of the New York City Department of Correction, was struggling to restore order in the Rikers Island jail complex when he asked a jail union boss for a meeting in the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Before Omicron, Britain’s economy regained its prepandemic size.
description: The economic output for November was bolstered by construction and manufacturing. But December data is likely to show the impact of a surge in virus cases.
content: In November, the month before Omicron swept through Britain, the nation’s economy reached a milestone: It surpassed its prepandemic size for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Candy Cornucopia
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photograph — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Pay on Wall Street will surge after a bumper year.
description: Quarterly profit at JPMorgan Chase was down, but it still earned a record $48.3 billion for the year. Citi’s annual profit nearly doubled, even though quarterly profit fell 26 percent.
content: Coming off a year of blockbuster profits, Wall Street is handing out fatter paychecks even as uncertainty creeps into the economic outlook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Novak Djokovic has legal options but they are narrow.
description: A second appeal of his canceled visa to enter Australia faces tougher hurdles and less chance of success.
content: Novak Djokovic’s lawyers on Saturday morning were expected to challenge the Australian immigration minister’s decision to cancel his visa again, but experts said that he would find it much more difficult than his first court challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: John Bowman, Comedy Writer With a Knack for Crossing Over, Dies at 64
description: A white writer who left a corporate job, he became known for working on series with Black stars like Keenen Ivory Wayans and Martin Lawrence.
content: John Bowman, a white television comedy writer and producer who left the corporate world to find success on Black-centered shows like “In Living Color” and “Martin,” died on Dec. 28 at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Manchester City, Chelsea and Competing With Perfection
description: Pep Guardiola’s ideas and his teams have changed the way England views the game. The danger is that those changes affect perceptions of what qualifies as success.
content: For a few weeks, around this time last year, English soccer found itself in a heartfelt, sincere discussion over whether the time had come for Éderson, Manchester City’s goalkeeper, to start taking penalties. Questions were asked on television. The subject was weighed in newspapers. Soccer’s commentariat chewed over the idea’s merits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Taking On Starbucks, Inspired by Bernie Sanders
description: The liberal workers the company has long attracted are expanding a union campaign to other cities after a landmark victory in Buffalo.
content: Maggie Carter, a Starbucks barista in Knoxville, Tenn., is a warm and reassuring presence who says she is keen to “go the extra mile” for customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Once a Trump Foil, Michael Avenatti Says Jail Treatment Was Payback
description: Mr. Avenatti, who was convicted of trying to extort Nike, is awaiting trial in New York on charges that he stole about $300,000 from Stormy Daniels.
content: Michael Avenatti, who rose to prominence as the lawyer representing a pornographic film actress in lawsuits against former President Donald J. Trump and was later convicted of trying to extort Nike, is seeking millions of dollars in compensation for harsh jail conditions that he says were retaliation for his outspoken criticism of Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Secret Triumph of Economic Policy
description: Why Covid-19 cost us fewer jobs than the dot-com bust.
content: All the reporting these days is about rising prices. And I get that: A 7 percent surge in the Consumer Price Index over the past year comes as a shock, especially because so many people, myself included, didn’t see it coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Amanda Holpuch
title: A Bill Proposed a New Way to Teach History. It Got the History Wrong.
description: A Republican legislator in Virginia who campaigned against critical race theory introduced a bill that incorrectly said the Lincoln-Douglas debates were between Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass.
content: Amid a flurry of bills nationwide that seek to ban the teaching of critical race theory in schools, one such proposal in Virginia stood out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro, Jeffery C. Mays and Lola Fadulu
title: Mayor Adams says he is weighing a ‘temporary’ remote learning option.
description: The city and the teachers union have been unable to agree on whether teachers should be allowed to livestream their lessons to students at home. Without an agreement, a remote option is unlikely.
content: Mayor Eric Adams said on Thursday his administration is considering a “temporary” remote learning option for the significant number of students who are already staying home during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: One Indelible Scene: When the Show Must Go on in ‘Drive My Car’
description: Through a staging of “Uncle Vanya,” the director Ryusuke Hamaguchi creates an intimacy for his characters that lets the artifice of cinema fall away.
content: I’m going to talk about how the movie ends, but I’m not going to spoil it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Landmark Conviction on Syrian War Crimes
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 14, 2022.
content: “This was a very important verdict. The signal is: There is no safe haven for war criminals. It’s a clear sign that the world will not stand by and do nothing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: He Makes Justin Bieber and the Bee Gees Go Viral on TikTok
description: Griffin Haddrill is a founder of VRTCL, an agency hired to turn hit songs into memes.
content: Name: Griffin Haddrill
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Connection. Adventure. Zest. Readers Choose Their Words of the Year.
description: Picking a word of the year helps you focus on the positive changes you’d like to make in your life, no matter what 2022 might have in store.
content: Last week, I challenged readers of this newsletter to come up with a single word to set the tone of their life for the next 12 months. I was wowed by both the creativity and the positivity from the thousands of readers who shared their words of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: An ominous outcome of talks with Russia.
content: Russian officials signaled yesterday that they might abandon diplomatic efforts to resolve the security crisis surrounding Ukraine, bringing a whirlwind week of talks to an ominous end and deflating hopes that negotiators could move to ease tensions in Eastern Europe. Russia’s next move will most likely be up to its president, Vladimir Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Cecilia Kang
title: Martin Shkreli is barred from the drug industry and ordered to repay $64.6 million.
description: A federal judge found that Mr. Shkreli violated state and federal antitrust laws by trying to maintain a monopoly over a lifesaving drug and must pay back the excess profits.
content: Martin Shkreli, the former pharmaceutical executive best known for unapologetically hiking the price of a lifesaving medication, must pay $64.6 million and will be barred for life from the drug industry for violating antitrust law, a federal court ordered on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Google’s chief executive signed off on deal at center of antitrust case, states say.
description: The states argue that Google reached a deal with Facebook to have the social network join its effort in an effort to “kill” a competing ad network.
content: Google’s chief executive approved an agreement with Facebook at the heart of an antitrust lawsuit that 16 states and Puerto Rico have lodged against the search giant, according to a portion of the complaint revealed on Friday.
